statement.p: Explain why the vectors \left[\begin{array}{r} 4 \\ 4 \\ 4 \\ 3 \\ -1 \end{array}\right] , \left[\begin{array}{r} 0 \\ -5 \\ -4 \\ -1 \\ 3 \end{array}\right] , \left[\begin{array}{r} -1 \\ 1 \\ 1 \\ -5 \\ -4 \end{array}\right] , \left[\begin{array}{r} 6 \\ 10 \\ 10 \\ -4 \\ -10 \end{array}\right] , \text{ and } \left[\begin{array}{r} 4 \\ 3 \\ -4 \\ 2 \\ -5 \end{array}\right] are or are not a basis of \mathbb{R}^5

answer.p: The vectors \left[\begin{array}{r} 4 \\ 4 \\ 4 \\ 3 \\ -1 \end{array}\right] , \left[\begin{array}{r} 0 \\ -5 \\ -4 \\ -1 \\ 3 \end{array}\right] , \left[\begin{array}{r} -1 \\ 1 \\ 1 \\ -5 \\ -4 \end{array}\right] , \left[\begin{array}{r} 6 \\ 10 \\ 10 \\ -4 \\ -10 \end{array}\right] , \text{ and } \left[\begin{array}{r} 4 \\ 3 \\ -4 \\ 2 \\ -5 \end{array}\right] are not a basis of \mathbb{R}^5.
